title: BBVA has launched a fully digital onboarding experience for business clients
text:
This story was delivered to Business Insider Intelligence Banking subscribers earlier this morning.

To get this story plus others to your inbox each day, hours before they're published on Business Insider, click here.

BBVA launched a new service that enables prospective business banking customers to become BBVA Spain customers via a completely online process. To use the service, businesses need to verify their ID with a joint administrator's digital certificate — issued by Spain's National Mint and Stamp Factory — and have self-signing software installed. Business Insider Intelligence

The bank claims the entire process takes under 10 minutes and notes that it complies with "current legislation and with the highest standards of security," per Oscar Velez de Mendizabal, head of BBVA's business transformation factory.

This innovation comes as small- and medium-sized business (SMB) banking neobanks expand throughout the EU, increasing competition for the region's 24 million SMBs. There are over 21 providers in the SMB digital banking space in Europe, far more than the Americas' eight providers and Asia's six, per data from Medici cited by Fintech Switzerland.

And those digital banks are growing in the EU, which ups their threat on incumbents: UK business banking platform Tide recently raised £44 million ($54 million) in Series B funding for expansion in the UK and internationally, and neobank Starling has been fleshing out its business banking marketplace.

Services like BBVA's end-to-end digital onboarding for business will be critical for incumbent banks across the EU looking to stave off digital challengers. Online services that make business banking more accessible and less complicated are attractive to business clients, and can be especially useful for new and emerging companies that may lack the staff to dedicate to banking functions.

For digital challenger banks, which are relatively young and have no physical presence or legacy systems, innovating such digital tools is naturally top-of-mind. Incumbents should focus on them as well, but they don't necessarily have to develop entire suites of SMB banking tools in-house — they also have the option of partnering with fintechs or even dipping into their sizeable tech budgets to acquire fledgling digital competitors completely.

BBVA itself serves as an example of taking a mixed approach to digital transformation in business banking: While it has recently developed tools like an intelligent account aggregator and a digital process for requesting guarantees, it also outright acquired Finnish online business banking service Holvi in 2016.
